Effect of titania structure on palladium oxide catalysts in the oxidative coupling of 4-methylpyridine Justin J. Dodson 1 Helena E. Hagelin-Weaver ⁎ University of Florida, Department of Chemical Engineering, P.O. Box 116 005, Gainesville, FL 32611, USA University of Florida Department of Chemical Engineering P.O. Box 116 005 Gainesville FL 32611 USA ⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: +1 3523929513. 1 Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77204, USA Graphical abstract The effects of anatase and rutile titania on PdO/TiO2 catalysts and how these phases influence the activity in the oxidative coupling of 4-methylpyridine to 4,4′-dimethyl-2,2′-bipyridine were investigated. The anatase and rutile concentrations were systematically varied by heat treating a nearly amorphous nanoparticle titania at temperatures between 105 and 800°C. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements confirmed that the anatase concentration increased with heat treatment temperature until rutile began to form at 600°C, and at 800°C rutile TiO2 was the only phase observed. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of the catalysts revealed strong PdO-TiO2 interactions which increased with support treatment temperature. According to XPS, the interactions yielded electron-deficient PdO species (Pdδ+ with δ>2) and Ti3+ species (likely TiO2 with oxygen vacancies) on the surface of the catalysts, as a result of electron transfer from palladium to titania. These PdO-TiO2 interactions increased with increasing anatase phase in the TiO2 support and the turnover number (TON: number of product molecules formed per surface palladium site) followed the same trend. The strongest interactions (the largest amounts of Pdδ+ with δ>2 and Ti3+ species) were observed for the catalysts supported on rutile TiO2, which is also the catalyst with the highest TON, revealing the importance of electron transfer from palladium to titania in this reaction. Despite the high TON for PdO on rutile TiO2, the anatase-supported PdO gave a significantly higher product yield due to the very low surface area of rutile TiO2. Keywords Palladium oxide Anatase and rutile TiO2 Aromatic coupling XRD XPS 1 Introduction Palladium catalysts supported on titanium dioxide (Pd/TiO2) are very versatile and have been used in a number of reactions, ranging from complete oxidations [1–3] to selective hydrogenations [4–13], hydrodechlorination [14], NO x reduction [15,16], and even Heck reactions [17]. Pd/TiO2 catalysts have also been used in the acetoxylation of toluene [18,19], and are commonly used in photocatalytic oxidation reactions due to the properties of the TiO2 support [20,21]. It is well known that high-temperature reduction of Pd/TiO2 catalysts can induce strong metal support interactions (SMSI) [22,23]. These metal-support interactions can lead to a partially reduced titania support (i.e. oxygen vacancies and the presence of Ti3+ due to hydrogen spillover from palladium) and titania migration over the active palladium sites [24]. While this can potentially lead to more stable catalysts (as palladium particle growth, i.e. sintering, is hindered by the titania) and also more selective catalysts (a reduction in coking), the titania is also covering active palladium species which can result in lower catalytic activities [24]. Most studies of Pd/TiO2 catalysts involve reduction to induce strong metal support interactions [6–9,22–24]. However, there are indications that strong interactions are present even for PdO/TiO2 catalysts, i.e. between the palladium oxide and the titania support on non-reduced catalysts [21], and oxygen spillover from palladium to titania has also been observed [25,26]. Strong interactions between PdO and TiO2 can be manifested in PdO decomposition at lower temperatures compared with PdO supported on, for example, Al2O3 [27–30]. Furthermore, Pd-TiO2 interactions are dependent on the structure of the titania support. Titania has two main crystal structures of importance in catalysis, namely anatase and rutile [31], although brookite has also been identified in catalysts [12,13]. The anatase phase is widely used as catalyst support because of its large specific surface area, but this phase has a low thermal stability. At higher temperatures the anatase phase is converted into the more stable rutile phase [31,32]. Unfortunately, this phase transition to rutile is associated with a significant loss in surface area [31], which is typically highly undesirable in catalysis. However, rutile can have favorable catalytic properties in some reactions despite the low surface area [18,20,33]. Reduction of titania-supported catalysts, at temperatures as low as 200°C, leads to strong favorable interactions between palladium and the anatase TiO2 support [15,31]. In contrast, rutile TiO2 requires higher reduction temperatures than anatase to induce SMSI [15,23]. The higher temperature needed for SMSI on rutile TiO2 may be because the less stable anatase TiO2 is easier to reduce than rutile TiO2 [7]. Due to the differences in metal-support interactions between the TiO2 phases, the catalytic activity and selectivity of palladium supported on anatase versus rutile TiO2 can be markedly different [18]. In our previous research, we have shown that palladium oxide supported on a porous anatase titania (p-TiO2) is more active in the oxidative coupling of 4-methylpyridine to 4,4′-dimethyl-2,2′-bipyridine than PdO on a nearly amorphous nanoparticle TiO2 (n-TiO2), despite the significantly larger surface area (505m2/g) of n-TiO2 compared with p-TiO2 (120m2/g) [34]. Strong PdO x -TiO2 interactions were identified on the TiO2-supported catalysts resulting in slightly more electron-deficient PdO species compared with PdO on the surface of a non-interacting support, such as Al2O3 [35]. However, except for varying anatase concentrations no other difference was observed over the TiO2-supported catalysts to explain the catalytic behavior [34]. Therefore, the objectives of this study were to investigate the metal-support interactions of PdO/TiO2 catalysts in detail, and determine how they vary with TiO2 structure, as well as how these interactions influence the oxidative coupling of 4-methylpyridine. A series of PdO catalysts supported on TiO2 with different structures (ranging from nearly amorphous to anatase and rutile) were prepared and carefully characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalysts were prepared using commercially available titanium dioxide nanoparticles (n-TiO2, NanoScale Corporation), porous titania pellets (p-TiO2, Alfa Aesar), and rutile titania powder (r-TiO2, Sigma–Aldrich). The titania pellets were crushed before catalyst preparation, and the nanoparticle TiO2 was pretreated in air at 105°C, 350°C, 450°C, 600°C, or 800°C for 3h in a muffle furnace. A precipitation method was used to deposit palladium onto the supports. For this method, an aqueous solution of palladium nitrate (Pd(NO3)2·2H2O, Sigma–Aldrich) was added to an aqueous dispersion of the titania support. The mixture was titrated with an aqueous solution of sodium hydroxide (Sigma–Aldrich) to form palladium hydroxide(s) on the support (using 50% stoichiometric excess of hydroxide based on the amount of palladium nitrate) [36]. The resulting mixture was aged overnight at room temperature before being filtered. The filtered material was rinsed in deionized water overnight and filtered again. The recovered material was then dried at 105°C overnight and calcined in air at 350°C for 3h, unless otherwise noted. In two cases, higher calcination temperatures, 600°C and 800°C, were used. In all cases, the palladium loading was 5% by weight on a metal basis. 2.2 Reaction conditions The reactant, 4-methylpyridine (Acros), was doubly distilled over KOH prior to use. In a typical reaction, 0.7g of catalyst was placed in a round bottom flask with 7g of distilled 4-methylpyridine. The reaction mixture was evacuated before introducing an oxygen atmosphere. The mixture was then heated to the boiling point (145°C) under continuous agitation. After refluxing for 72h, the flask contents were washed with chloroform to dissolve the product and filtered using a glass micro-fiber filter. The product was obtained by removing the chloroform, water, and unreacted 4-methylpyridine using a rotary evaporator. The yields are reported as the amount of product formed per unit weight of catalyst or palladium. A turnover number was defined as the number of moles of product formed per mole of surface palladium calculated based on the CO titration measurements. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The as-received support surface areas (after drying over night at 105°C), the pretreated support surface areas, and the surface areas of the prepared catalysts were determined by multipoint Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) isotherms on a Quantachrome Nova 1200 instrument as described in previous work [37]. Chemisorption measurements were performed in a Quantachrome ChemBET 3000 instrument and used to characterize the active metal surface area. The catalysts were first reduced with 5% hydrogen in nitrogen at 170°C for 1h, and then outgassed in nitrogen at 170°C for another hour. The mild conditions were used to limit sintering of the Pd particles on the surface. This was followed by pulse titrating carbon monoxide over the reduced catalysts to measure the CO adsorbed and determine the palladium surface area and dispersion of the catalysts. Detailed descriptions of the procedure and calculations are given in previous work [34]. While PdO is believed to be the active phase, or at least a necessary precursor, the CO chemisorption measurements on reduced catalysts are important since the PdO surface cannot be measured directly. It is assumed that there is a correlation between the original PdO surface area and the Pd surface area of the reduced catalyst. Previous XRD and TEM data support this assumption [35]. The turnover number (TON), i.e. the number of moles of product formed per mole of surface palladium, was calculated from the product yield and the CO adsorbed on the catalyst using a Pd:CO stoichiometry of 1:1. The XRD data were gathered on a PANalytical X′Pert Powder X-ray diffractometer using Bragg-Brentano geometry with Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.54Å). The supports and catalyst powders were secured onto a glass slide with double-sided sticky tape prior to the measurements. XPS was performed on selected fresh catalysts using a custom built instrument equipped with a double-pass cylindrical mirror analyzer (PHI model 25-270 AR). The catalyst powders were pressed into aluminum cups prior to insertion into the ultra-high vacuum (UHV) chamber (base pressure 1×10−10 Torr). Spectra were taken in retarding mode with a pass energy of 50eV for survey spectra and 25eV for high-resolution spectra using a Mg Kα X-ray source (PHI04-151). Data were collected using a computer interface and then digitally smoothed. A value for the C 1s binding energy of 284.6eV was assigned to correct for static charging and work function differences [38]. 3 Results and discussion Several PdO/TiO2 catalysts were prepared using different titania supports: a porous anatase support (p-TiO2), a commercially available rutile TiO2, (r-TiO2), and a nearly amorphous n-TiO2 support. The latter was heat treated at increasing temperatures between 105°C and 800°C to systematically increase the contribution from the anatase phase until the temperature was sufficiently high for rutile formation. All of the PdO/TiO2 catalysts were tested for activity in the oxidative coupling of 4-methylpyridine and characterized using a number of analytical techniques. 3.1 Surface area measurements The measured specific surface areas, one of the more important support properties, of the different TiO2 supports are presented in Table 1 . For the commercial anatase and rutile supports (p-TiO2 and r-TiO2, respectively), the surface area was measured after drying at 105°C for 2h (the pretreatment before palladium deposition), while for the nanoparticle TiO2 the surface area was measured as a function of heat treatment temperature between 105°C and 800°C (see Table 1). As expected, the n-TiO2 surface area (190m2/g) is higher than the surface areas of the p-TiO2 and r-TiO2, and the p-TiO2 SSA (120m2/g) is a factor of five higher than the r-TiO2 SSA (24m2/g). However, the surface area of the n-TiO2 is evidently unstable. The original specific surface area of this support was 505m2/g, but after exposure to the atmosphere for several months the SSA had decreased to 190m2/g. The surface area of the n-TiO2 also decreased as a function of heat treatment temperature, due to sintering (i.e. particle growth). The SSA at 450°C (96m2/g) is only half of that at 105°C (190m2/g). Then there is a drastic decrease in SSA between heat treatment temperatures of 450°C and 600°C, which is likely due to the beginning of a phase change from anatase to rutile (vide infra). After calcination at 800°C, the n-TiO2 surface area (2.3m2/g) is almost two orders of magnitude smaller than the original surface area. In fact, this surface area is an order of magnitude lower than the commercial rutile TiO2. After PdO deposition the catalyst surface areas are, in general, slightly lower than the SSA of the support. This is common on high surface area supports as the deposited PdO can block some of the pores in the support during deposition. However, for the lowest support surface area, the n-TiO2 heat treated at 800°C (2.3m2/g), adding palladium actually results in an increase in the overall surface area to 5m2/g. The catalyst surface areas measured after palladium deposition reveal that the palladium does not completely block the pores of the supports, nor do the preparation conditions lead to destruction of the supports (as both of these cases would lead to a drastically lower catalyst surface area compared with the support surface area). The amount of CO adsorbed on the catalysts was measured after reduction to evaluate the available PdO on the surface of these catalysts. This works well on non-reducible supports, as it would be expected that the number of active PdO sites correlate fairly well with the number of active Pd sites determined from the CO adsorption on the reduced catalysts. To minimize strong-metal support interactions that can lead to partial reduction of the support, as well as migration of the support over the palladium, the reduction temperature was kept low (170°C) in this study. Under these conditions, it is expected that the measured Pd surface area will correlate reasonably well with the PdO available for reaction even for reducible supports, such as TiO2. The highest CO uptake is observed on the PdO/n-TiO2-105 catalyst, but the amount of CO adsorbed on the reduced n-TiO2-supported catalysts decrease with increasing pretreatment temperature. This suggests that the Pd surface area also decreases with increasing treatment temperature, which would be expected with decreasing support surface area. In fact, it appears that the support surface area is the main property which determines the palladium surface area. The correlation between the support surface area and the CO adsorbed on the catalyst prepared using that support is close to linear (Fig. 1 ). The CO volumes adsorbed on the rutile and the anatase TiO2 are also close to this relationship. This indicates that there are no special palladium-titania interactions during catalyst preparation which result in a higher palladium surface area than expected from the support surface area. Instead, the anatase, rutile and the amorphous TiO2 behave similarly in terms of providing a support surface area on which to disperse palladium. The low Pd surface area of the r-TiO2 catalyst is therefore due to the lower surface area on the PdO/r-TiO2 support compared to the other TiO2 supports, and is not due to weaker PdO x -TiO2 interactions compared with the anatase TiO2. 3.2 Reaction results The 4,4′-dimethyl-2,2′-bipyridine product yields obtained in the oxidative coupling of 4-methylpyridine over the different PdO/TiO2 catalysts (Scheme 1 ) are summarized in Table 1 and Fig. 2 . The best performing catalyst is the PdO/p-TiO2 with a product yield of 52 g/g palladium. As noted previously, this is a much higher yield compared with the PdO/n-TiO2-105 catalyst despite the lower CO adsorption on the PdO/p-TiO2 catalyst. Based on the measured CO adsorption the turnover number is 210 for the PdO/p-TiO2 catalyst and only 70 for the PdO/n-TiO2-105 catalyst. This suggests that the PdO on the surface of the PdO/p-TiO2 is more active than the PdO on the surface of the PdO/n-TiO2-105 catalyst. One explanation for this is that the TiO2 crystal phase influences the yields on TiO2-supported catalysts, as observed previously [18,31]. The results from the rutile TiO2-supported catalyst further supports this conclusion. The yield from the PdO/r-TiO2 catalyst is roughly half of that obtained from the PdO/p-TiO2 catalyst, and it is slightly lower than the yield obtained from the PdO/n-TiO2-105 catalyst. However, considering that the Pd surface area of the PdO/r-TiO2 support is only a third of the Pd surface area on the PdO/p-TiO2, an even lower yield would be expected from the r-TiO2-supported catalyst. Therefore, the TON is higher on the PdO/r-TiO2 catalyst (TON=290) compared to the other PdO/TiO2 catalysts (TON{PdO/p-TiO2}=210 and TON{PdO/n-TiO2-105}=70, Table 1). Hence, the PdO on the surface of the r-TiO2 support is more active than PdO on the other TiO2 supports, but the product yield obtained per unit weight of catalyst is lower due to the low surface area of the r-TiO2 support. The lowest TON of the catalysts in the study is obtained over the PdO/n-TiO2-105 catalyst, but the TON increases with support treatment temperature for this catalyst. As the anatase phase is expected to grow with increasing temperature, the trend in TON is likely due to the increasing contribution from anatase in the TiO2 support. Despite the decrease in Pd surface area with increasing support treatment temperature, the product yield per unit weight of catalyst increases up to 450°C for the PdO/n-TiO2 catalysts (due to the increasing TON). Therefore, the maximum yield from the n-TiO2-supported catalysts is obtained after support treatment at 450°C. At support treatment temperatures above 450°C a drastic drop in yield is observed with only 15g product/g Pd at 600°C and 8g product/g Pd at 800°C. Table 1 reveals that the main reason for the drastic drop in product yield is due to the loss in support surface area, and thus reduction in palladium surface area, associated with the higher pretreatment temperatures. At a pretreatment temperature of 800°C, the CO adsorption is an order of magnitude lower than for the PdO/n-TiO2-450 catalyst (Table 1). As for the PdO/r-TiO2 catalyst, the product yields obtained from the PdO/n-TiO2-600 and PdO/n-TiO2-800 catalysts are higher than would be expected from the estimated Pd surface area (obtained from the CO adsorption measurements). This and the drastic drop in TiO2 surface area suggest that a pretreatment temperature of 600°C is sufficient to induce rutile formation. In fact, the turnover numbers for the PdO/n-TiO2-600 (TON=255) and PdO/n-TiO2-800 (TON=370) catalysts are closer to the TON for the PdO/r-TiO2 catalyst (TON=290) than the PdO/p-TiO2 catalyst (TON=210). The higher TON observed for the PdO/n-TiO2-800 compared with the PdO/r-TiO2 could be due to an underestimation of the Pd surface area on the PdO/n-TiO2-800 catalyst due to the significantly larger Pd particles (which would be expected to result in more bridge-bound CO compared to smaller Pd particles, and thus a CO:Pd stoichiometry between 1:1 and 1:2). The true TON for PdO/n-TiO2-800 is likely closer to that observed over the PdO/r-TiO2 catalyst. Thus, the turnover number increases with increasing pretreatment temperature of the n-TiO2 support, and this is true for all PdO/n-TiO2 catalysts under investigation. Support pretreatments at 600°C and 800°C evidently cause a severe reduction in support surface area (Table 1), which in turn limits the active PdO surface area that can be obtained on these supports. Therefore, despite the higher turnover numbers on these catalysts, the higher activity per palladium site cannot counterbalance the significantly lower PdO surface area on the PdO/n-TiO2-600 and PdO/n-TiO2-800 catalysts. The result is very low product yields over these catalysts. In an attempt to increase the PdO surface area of the PdO/n-TiO2 catalyst while keeping the turnover number the same, one catalyst was prepared using n-TiO2 support pretreated at 105°C (with the highest support surface area) and then calcined at 600°C after palladium deposition. The product yield obtained from the PdO/n-TiO2-M600 is almost double that obtained from the PdO/n-TiO2-600 catalyst. This is clearly due to a higher PdO surface area (CO adsorption) on this catalyst as the turnover numbers are indeed the same for the PdO/n-TiO2-600 and PdO/n-TiO2-M600 catalysts. Additionally, another catalyst was prepared to determine if the TON on a high yield catalyst (PdO/n-TiO2-450) can be increased by calcination at 800°C. The product yield of PdO/n-TiO2-M800 is only a fourth of the yield obtained over the PdO/n-TiO2-450, but it is slightly higher than that obtained over the PdO/n-TiO2-800 catalyst. Unfortunately, the palladium on the surface of the PdO/n-TiO2-450 catalyst is not very stable during calcination at 800°C. The measured Pd surface area is somewhat lower on the PdO/n-TiO2-M800 compared with the PdO/n-TiO2-800 catalyst. Therefore, since the Pd surface area is lower and the product yield is higher on the PdO/n-TiO2-M800 catalyst, the TON is indeed significantly higher (TON=680), compared with the PdO/n-TiO2-800 catalyst (TON=370, Table 1). The very high TON could be due to an underestimated PdO surface area as discussed above, although Pd formation in the bulk of the particles due to PdO decomposition at the high-temperature calcination treatment cannot be excluded [30]. Despite the high TONs, the product yields obtained from the catalysts calcined at 600°C and 800°C are very low due to the small palladium surface areas, and these catalysts can therefore not compete with the other PdO/n-TiO2 catalysts (which have lower TON, but significantly higher Pd surface areas). 3.3 XRD measurements The XRD patterns obtained from the titania supports before palladium deposition are presented in Fig. 3 (a). The peaks due to the rutile phase of the r-TiO2 and the anatase phase of the p-TiO2 supports are labeled in the figure. The crystal sizes of the r-TiO2 and p-TiO2 supports according the Scherrer equation are 12 and 20nm, respectively (Table 2 ). The XRD data confirms that as the pretreatment temperature increases, the initially amorphous n-TiO2 begins to crystallize into an anatase phase. At a pretreatment temperature of 350°C the anatase crystal size has grown to 10nm and at 450°C it is 12nm. The 600°C heat treatment yields very sharp peaks due to the anatase phase and the peak widths indicate crystal sizes of 27nm. In addition, peaks due to the rutile phase also appear in the XRD pattern after the 600°C heat-treatment, and the average rutile particle size is larger (36nm) than the anatase crystallites (Table 2). Complete transformation to rutile (according to XRD) has occurred after the 800°C heat treatment (Figs. 3), although the crystallite size has not increased past the 36nm. The formation of the rutile phase above 800°C has been reported along with a severe decrease in surface area [32], which is consistent with the XRD data in Fig. 3 and the decrease in TiO2 surface area from the initial 190m2/g to 2.3m2/g after the 800°C calcination. The XRD patterns obtained from the catalysts, i.e. after palladium deposition, are very similar to the XRD patterns obtained from the supports at the same heat treatment temperature (Fig. 3). The only exception is the PdO/n-TiO2-105, where the amorphous n-TiO2-105 has crystallized into an anatase phase after catalyst preparation. This is expected, since the catalyst preparation involves a calcination at 350°C for 3h. Comparing the XRD patterns obtained from the PdO/n-TiO2-105 catalyst after calcination at 350°C for 3h and the n-TiO2-350 support, it appears that the PdO/n-TiO2-105 catalyst has smaller anatase TiO2 crystallites. The average TiO2 particle size of the PdO/n-TiO2-105 catalyst is only 8nm compared to the 10nm TiO2 particles for the n-TiO2-350 support. Since the PdO/n-TiO2-105 catalyst and the n-TiO2-350 support have been exposed to the same treatment (calcination at 350°C) it appears that the presence of palladium retards the formation of anatase in the n-TiO2 support (vide infra). As mentioned, the XRD data confirm that the contribution from the anatase phase increases with n-TiO2 treatment temperature and, since the turnover numbers for the PdO/n-TiO2 catalysts follow the same trend, it suggests that the PdO on the surface is more active on anatase TiO2 compared with amorphous high surface area TiO2. This is particularly evident when comparing the PdO/n-TiO2-105 and PdO/n-TiO2-350 catalysts since these two catalysts have different PdO surface areas, yet yield the same amount of product. Since the PdO/n-TiO2-105 has the higher PdO surface area, the TON is higher on the PdO/n-TiO2-350 catalyst. One explanation for this could be because the anatase phase is more developed on the PdO/n-TiO2-350 compared with the PdO/n-TiO2-105 catalyst. The XRD data also verify rutile formation after calcination at 600°C which was previously implied due to the drastic decrease in support surface area between 400 and 600°C. At a support treatment temperature of 800°C only rutile is observed in the XRD data, and since the PdO/n-TiO2-800 has the highest TON of the non-modified PdO/n-TiO2 catalysts, it indicates that PdO on rutile is even more active than PdO on anatase. However, since rutile anatase TiO2 has a very low surface area, the PdO surface area is limited and the yield obtained from the PdO/n-TiO2-800 is therefore the lowest observed in the study. Even though there is a clear decrease in PdO surface area (suggesting increasing Pd particle sizes) according to the CO titration measurements with increasing heat treatment temperature of the support, it appears that the PdO on the surface is not very crystalline. The peaks due to PdO cannot be detected on the PdO/n-TiO2-105 catalyst (Fig. 4 ), and the average PdO particle sizes according to the Scherrer equation are all within 7 and 9nm for the catalysts on the n-TiO2 supports heat treated between 350 and 800°C. This indicates that a significant amount of the PdO on the support is amorphous, and thus not detected with XRD. This may be expected since the palladium has not been exposed to temperatures above 350°C. This is not true for the PdO/n-TiO2-M600 and PdO/n-TiO2-M800 catalysts (Table 2), and the Pd particle sizes according to the Scherrer equation are larger for these catalysts (11 and 22nm, respectively). The XRD pattern obtained from the PdO/n-TiO2-M600 catalyst, a PdO catalyst supported on n-TiO2-105 which was calcined at 600°C after PdO deposition, is somewhat surprising. This temperature is sufficient to induce rutile formation in the n-TiO2 support, yet anatase is the only phase observed in the XRD pattern obtained from PdO/n-TiO2-M600 (Fig. 4). This is despite the fact that the TON is the same as for the PdO/n-TiO2-600 catalyst, which indicates the presence of a rutile phase. Evidently, the presence of PdO during high-temperature calcination prevents formation of bulk rutile, which is why the overall surface area is higher on the PdO/n-TiO2-M600 compared with the PdO/n-TiO2-600 catalyst. Instead, the anatase TiO2 particle sizes are larger (36nm) than maximum anatase particle size (27nm) observed on the heat treated n-TiO2 support (Table 2). Since the TON of the PdO/n-TiO2-M600 catalyst indicate the presence of rutile, it is possible that small rutile crystallites with particle sizes below the detection limit of XRD or a surface rutile phase with no long-range order (also XRD invisible) have started to develop at the surface of this catalyst. As expected, the PdO particles in the PdO/n-TiO2-M600 catalyst are larger (11nm) than on the PdO/n-TiO2-600 since the PdO was present during the 600°C calcination of the PdO/n-TiO2-M600 catalyst. Even on the PdO/n-TiO2-M800 catalyst, where the support was pretreated at 450°C, the catalyst calcined at 350°C after PdO deposition, and then heat treated at 800°C, no rutile phase can be observed, despite the fact that on the PdO/n-TiO2-800 catalyst rutile is the only evident TiO2 phase. Palladium addition, therefore, stabilizes the anatase phase of the TiO2 support and retards the formation of rutile in the bulk of the support, as has been observed previously [40]. However, the TON again suggests the presence of rutile at the surface of the catalyst, although evidently the crystal sizes are not sufficiently large for detection with XRD. Of course, the high temperature treatment also results in PdO particle growth, which is evident in the XRD patterns. The average PdO particle size is significantly larger (22nm) on the PdO/n-TiO2-M800 compared with the PdO/n-TiO2-800 (8nm). Evidently, the TiO2 support does not stabilize the PdO against sintering during the 800°C calcination, and the result is an even lower Pd surface area compared with the PdO/n-TiO2-800 catalyst (which had a low Pd surface area due to a low support surface area). While some of the trends may suggest that larger PdO particles are more active in the reaction, i.e. low dispersion catalysts would be beneficial, results on other supports reveal that this is not the case. The higher activity (TON) of the PdO/p-TiO2 catalyst with the lower Pd surface area compared with the PdO/n-TiO2 catalyst is unique to TiO2-supported catalysts. This further supports the conclusion that the crystal structure of the TiO2 support is very important in PdO/TiO2 catalysts. 3.4 XPS measurements As XRD is a bulk technique which does not provide information about surface properties, it was decided to also analyze selected catalysts using XPS to obtain detailed information on the oxidation states of the surface species and palladium-titania interactions. Since the survey spectra obtained from these catalysts are similar, and dominated by the O 1s peak, only the region from 500 to 0eV is displayed in Fig. 5 . The survey spectra have been normalized to give Ti 2p peaks of similar intensity to facilitate comparisons between catalysts. The most evident difference between the spectra obtained from the catalysts is the variation in the Pd 3d peak intensities. The highest Pd 3d peak intensities are observed on the PdO/n-TiO2-600 and PdO/n-TiO2-800 catalysts and reveal that palladium does not penetrate the heat treated n-TiO2 supports and is deposited on the outermost surface of these catalysts. This is expected due to the low surface areas of the n-TiO2-600 and n-TiO2-800 supports. For the same reason, the Pd 3d peak intensities are higher on the PdO/r-TiO2 compared to the other PdO/n-TiO2 catalysts. The Pd 3d, Ti 2p and O 1s peaks obtained from the PdO/n-TiO2 catalysts as a function of support pretreatment temperature are presented in Fig. 6 , together with the XPS data obtained from the PdO/p-TiO2 and PdO/r-TiO2 catalysts. The Ti 2p3/2 peaks for PdO/p-TiO2 and PdO/r-TiO2 catalysts are both located at a binding energy of 458.6eV consistent with TiO2 (Fig. 6a) [38]. However, compared to the Ti 2p3/2 peak obtained from the p-TiO2 support, the peaks are slightly broader on the low binding energy side of the peak after PdO deposition (Fig. 7 ). The contribution from the species at low binding energy is even higher on the PdO/n-TiO2-105, as evidenced in the shift of the Ti 2p3/2 peak to 458.4eV. The species at low binding energy is likely reduced TiO2 (Ti3+) due to oxygen vacancies on the surface of the TiO2 support. The shoulder at 457.5eV is reasonably close to the 457.8eV binding energy reported for Ti2O3, although lower binding energies have also been reported for Ti2O3 [41]. Literature data indicate that the formation of surface Ti3+ is easier on nanoparticle TiO2 compared with micron-sized TiO2 [9], which support the higher contribution from Ti3+ on the PdO/n-TiO2-105 compared with PdO/p-TiO2. Furthermore, shifts in the Ti 2p3/2 binding energy have been observed previously on anatase TiO2 after deposition of PdO [21]. As the support pretreatment temperature increases, the Ti 2p peaks become broader and shift to lower binding energies. The lowest Ti 2p3/2 binding energy (458.2eV) is observed after a pretreatment at 800°C. This suggests that the number of oxygen vacancies (Ti3+ species) on the surface of the n-TiO2-supported catalysts increases with the calcination temperature, and the highest number of Ti3+ species is observed on the rutile-supported PdO/n-TiO2 catalyst. Even though the Ti 2p3/2 peaks obtained from the PdO/p-TiO2 and PdO/r-TiO2 catalysts are centered at the same binding energy (458.6eV), the peak obtained from the rutile-supported catalyst is slightly broader (Fig. 6a). Therefore, also the PdO/r-TiO2 catalyst has more Ti3+ species on the surface than the PdO/p-TiO2 catalyst, although not as many as the PdO/n-TiO2-800 catalyst. One explanation for the higher amount of Ti3+ species on the PdO/n-TiO2-800 catalyst could be that the oxygen vacancies present in the nanoparticle TiO2 support are trapped during the transformation to rutile, and as soon as rutile has formed the diffusion of Ti3+ is limited [23]. Previous research revealed that the Pd 3d5/2 binding energies of the PdO/p-TiO2 and PdO/n-TiO2-105 catalysts are slightly higher (336.3eV) compared to the Pd 3d5/2 binding energy of PdO (336.1eV) [30], suggesting strong PdO-TiO2 interactions resulting in electron-deficient Pd2+ species (Pdδ+ with δ>2). The Pd 3d5/2 binding energy obtained from the PdO/r-TiO2 catalyst is still higher at 336.6eV (Fig. 6b), which indicates even stronger interactions between PdO and rutile TiO2 compared with PdO and anatase TiO2. Previous results have shown that electron-deficient PdO species are more active in the oxidative coupling of 4-methylpyridine than expected from their measured Pd surface area [30]. Therefore, the high Pd 3d5/2 binding energy is consistent with the higher TON observed on PdO/r-TiO2. As the support pretreatment temperature increases from 105°C to 450°C, the Pd 3d peaks obtained from the PdO/n-TiO2 catalysts broaden similar to the Ti 2p peaks. However, while the Ti 2p peaks shift to lower binding energies, the Pd 3d peaks shift to higher binding energies. This suggests that the PdO x -TiO2 interactions increase with support treatment temperature, and that the interactions result in transfer of electron density from palladium to titanium. The Pd 3d5/2 peak obtained from the PdO/n-TiO2-600 catalyst is broad and is centered at a binding energy of 336.4eV indicating a significant contribution from a PdO species interacting with rutile TiO2 (i.e. a PdO x species with a Pd 3d5/2 binding energy of 336.6eV). This is in agreement with the XRD data, which reveal the presence of rutile in this catalyst, and explains the high TON on this catalyst. After a heat treatment at 800°C only rutile TiO2 is observed with XRD and the Pd 3d5/2 binding energy of the PdO/n-TiO2-800 catalyst is 336.6eV, consistent with PdO on rutile TiO2. The XPS data shows that the PdO-TiO2 interactions (electron transfer between palladium and titania) increase with support treatment temperature and, since the turnover number also follows this trend this further supports that an electron deficient PdO is important in the oxidative coupling of 4-methylpyridine. The O 1s binding energy region is rather complex, as it contains contributions not only from several oxygen species (such as TiO2, PdO and possibly hydroxyl groups associated with either titania or palladium), but also from the Pd 3p3/2 peak. The O 1s binding energies obtained from the PdO/p-TiO2 and PdO/n-TiO2-105 catalysts are the same at 529.9eV, while the O 1s binding energy of the PdO/r-TiO2 is slightly lower at 529.7eV (Fig. 6c). Apart from the slight difference in O 1s binding energy, the main difference between these catalysts is a significantly higher contribution from hydroxyl groups at a binding energy of 531.5eV on the PdO/n-TiO2-105 catalyst. As the n-TiO2 support heat treatment increases to 350°C most of the hydroxyl groups are removed and the O 1s peak shifts to 529.7eV, suggesting that changes occur at the surface of these catalysts even at 350°C. The shift towards the O 1s binding energy of rutile is clearly advantageous, as the turnover number for this catalyst is higher than that of the PdO/n-TiO2-105 catalyst. As expected from the higher Pd 3d peak intensities in the survey spectra obtained from the PdO/n-TiO2-600 and PdO/n-TiO2-800 catalysts, the contribution from the Pd 3p3/2 peak increases with increasing support pretreatment temperature. This is clearly evident in the shoulder at 533eV in Fig. 6c. As with the Pd 3d peaks, it appears that the Pd 3p3/2 peak shifts to higher binding energies with increasing support treatment temperature. However, it is difficult to accurately determine the binding energy of the Pd 3p3/2 peak, due to the presence of several overlapping features in the O 1s region. The O 1s peaks obtained from PdO/n-TiO2-450, PdO/n-TiO2-600 and PdO/n-TiO2-800 catalysts are very broad on the high binding energy side of the TiO2-related O 1s peak at 529.7eV. This could be due to strongly bound hydroxyl groups or oxygen species associated with the electron deficient palladium oxide. Even the PdO/r-TiO2 catalyst has a small shoulder between the O 1s peak at 529.7eV and the Pd 3p3/2 peak at ∼533.6eV, which could be an oxygen species associated the electron-deficient palladium oxide. 4 Conclusions The influence of TiO2 crystal structure on TiO2-supported PdO catalysts was investigated and their activity evaluated in the oxidative coupling of 4-methylpyridine. The turnover number for the PdO/n-TiO2 catalysts increased with heat treatment temperature of the TiO2 support. XPS and XRD data revealed that this was due to increasing PdO-TiO2 interactions with increasing anatase concentration. The highest turnover numbers and the strongest interactions, i.e. the most electron-deficient PdO and the highest Ti3+ concentration, were obtained over PdO catalysts supported rutile TiO2. This explains the high TON for rutile-supported catalysts, but these catalysts are limited by their low support and PdO surface areas. The strong interactions do not appear to be present during the catalyst synthesis, as the PdO surface area correlates well with the support surface area. They likely form during calcination, but they are not sufficiently strong to prevent sintering of palladium during calcination at 800°C. Therefore, to increase the product yield beyond that of PdO/p-TiO2, it would be necessary to find a high surface area support that can stabilize TiO2 in a rutile-like phase, so that a higher PdO surface area together with the high TON of PdO on rutile TiO2 can be obtained. coredata.dc:description: The effects of anatase and rutile titania on PdO/TiO2 catalysts and how these phases influence the activity in the oxidative coupling of 4-methylpyridine to 4,4′-dimethyl-2,2′-bipyridine were investigated. The anatase and rutile concentrations were systematically varied by heat treating a nearly amorphous nanoparticle titania at temperatures between 105 and 800°C. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements confirmed that the anatase concentration increased with heat treatment temperature until rutile began to form at 600°C, and at 800°C rutile TiO2 was the only phase observed. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of the catalysts revealed strong PdO-TiO2 interactions which increased with support treatment temperature. According to XPS, the interactions yielded electron-deficient PdO species (Pdδ+ with δ>2) and Ti3+ species (likely TiO2 with oxygen vacancies) on the surface of the catalysts, as a result of electron transfer from palladium to titania. These PdO-TiO2 interactions increased with increasing anatase phase in the TiO2 support and the turnover number (TON: number of product molecules formed per surface palladium site) followed the same trend. The strongest interactions (the largest amounts of Pdδ+ with δ>2 and Ti3+ species) were observed for the catalysts supported on rutile TiO2, which is also the catalyst with the highest TON, revealing the importance of electron transfer from palladium to titania in this reaction. Despite the high TON for PdO on rutile TiO2, the anatase-supported PdO gave a significantly higher product yield due to the very low surface area of rutile TiO2.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of titania structure on palladium oxide catalysts in the oxidative coupling of 4-methylpyridine
